variable.name: Boolean1
variable.label: Boolean
variable.description: This sample shows a boolean variable, true or false. It is initially displayed checked or not, depending on the default value specified in the XML (in this example, true).

variable.name: String1
variable.label: Simple string
variable.description: This sample shows a basic string variable.

variable.name: String2
variable.label: String with a default
variable.description: This sample shows a string that is primed with the default value specified in the XML. Note that this variable is designated as required within the step. As such, the variable is displayed somewhat differently than the others.

variable.name: String3
variable.label: String with choices
variable.abstract: String with a list of choices.
variable.description: This variable value must come from a list of choices.

variable.name: String4
variable.label: String with optional choices
variable.abstract: String with a list of optional, translatable choices.
variable.description: What is your favorite color? Some suggestions are provided, but you are not required to select any of them.

variable.name: String5
variable.label: String with length constraints.
variable.abstract: String with a minimum and maximum length.
variable.description: In this sample, you must enter a string of between 5 and 15 characters, inclusive.

variable.name: String6
variable.label: String with choices
variable.abstract: String with a list of choices, a default, and a minimum and maximum length.
variable.description: All possible values must adhere to the minimum and maximum length.

variable.name: String7
variable.label: String with a regular expression.
variable.abstract: String constrained by a regular expression (regexp).
variable.description: You can enter basic text here. This field accepts upper- and lowercase characters, spaces, periods, commas, exclamation points, question marks, and apostrophes, but nothing else. You can specify up to 20 characters.

variable.name: String8
variable.label: String with regular expression, a default, and choices.
variable.abstract: String with a list of choices, a default, and a regular expression.
variable.description: All possible values must adhere to the regular expression, which enforces a 1-10 character alphanumeric string (no special characters).

variable.name: String9
variable.label: Multi-line string.
variable.description: Here, you have space to enter more a meaningful description, up to 100 characters.

variable.name: Integer1
variable.label: Integer
variable.description: This is an integer variable.

variable.name: Integer2
variable.label: Integer with default
variable.description: This field is primed with the default value specified in the XML.

variable.name: Integer3
variable.label: Integer
variable.abstract: Integer with a minimum and maximum value.
variable.description: An integer between -50 and 50.

variable.name: Decimal1
variable.label: Decimal
variable.abstract: Decimal variable, with up to three decimal places.
variable.description: Enter a decimal value with up to three decimal places. If you enter more than three, the value is considered invalid.

variable.name: Decimal2
variable.label: Decimal with default
variable.description: This field is primed with the default value specified in the XML. The number of decimal places defaults to one.

variable.name: Decimal3
variable.label: Decimal
variable.abstract: Decimal with a minimum and maximum value.
variable.description: A number between 3.333 and 9.999.

variable.name: Time1
variable.label: Time
variable.description: Time in UTC format. For example "12:00:00".

variable.name: Time2
variable.label: Time with criteria
variable.abstract: Time-of-day with a minimum, maximum, and default.
variable.description:
Time can have:
A minimum value
A maximum value
A default value

variable.name: Date1
variable.label: Date
variable.description: Date in UTC format. For example "2013-03-12".

variable.name: Date2
variable.label: Date with criteria
variable.abstract: Date with a minimum, maximum, and default.
variable.description: A dates can have a minimum, maximum, and default. Notice how the widget crosses-out the dates that are out of range.

variable.name: Char1
variable.label: ALPHA
variable.description: A validation type of ALPHA allows upper- and lowercase letters, and special characters (@, #, $).

variable.name: Char2
variable.label: ALPHAB
variable.description: A validation type of ALPHAB allows upper- and lowercase letters.

variable.name: Char3
variable.label: ALPHANUM
variable.description: A validation type of ALPHANUM allows upper- and lowercase letters, numerics, and special characters.

variable.name: Char4
variable.label: BIT
variable.description: A validation type of BIT allows only ones and zeros.

variable.name: Char5
variable.label: HEX
variable.description: A validation type of HEX allows a-f, A-F, and 0-9.

variable.name: Ds1
variable.label: DSMEMBERNAME
variable.description: A validation type of DSMEMBERNAME allows for 1-8 alphanumeric (uppercase only) characters, including special characters and "{". However, the name must start with a letter or special character.

variable.name: Ds2
variable.label: DSNAME
variable.description: A validation type of DSNAME allows a maximum of 44 alphanumeric (uppercase only) characters, including the special characters, and "-". However, the name must start with a letter or special character. The name consists of 1-8 character qualifiers, separated by a period.

variable.name: Ds3
variable.label: DSQUAL
variable.description: A validation type of DSQUAL allows for 1-8 alphanumeric (uppercase only) characters, including the special characters, and "-". However, the name must start with a letter or special character.

variable.name: Ds4
variable.label: VOLSER
variable.description: A validation type of VOLSER allows for 1-6 alphanumeric (uppercase only) characters.

variable.name: Id1
variable.label: GROUP
variable.description: A validation type of GROUP allows for 1-8 alphanumeric (uppercase only) characters, including the special characters. However, the name must start with a letter or special character.

variable.name: Id2
variable.label: TSOUSERID
variable.description: A validation type of TSOUSERID is similar to USERID, except the maximum length is 7, and it cannot start with a number.

variable.name: Id3
variable.label: UNIXID
variable.description: A validation type of UNIXID is an integer between 0 and 2147483647, inclusive.

variable.name: Id4
variable.label: USERID
variable.description: A validation type of USERID allows for 1-8 alphanumeric (uppercase only) characters, including special characters.

variable.name: Net1
variable.label: IPADDR4
variable.description: A validation type of IPADDR4 allows a valid IPV4 address. See the Internet Protocol RFC for details.

variable.name: Net2
variable.label: IPADDR6
variable.description: A validation type of IPADDR6 allows a valid IPV6 address. See the Internet Protocol RFC for details.

variable.name: Net3
variable.label: IPADDR
variable.description: A validation type of IPADDR allows a valid IPV4 or IPV6 address. See the Internet Protocol RFC for details.

step.name: VariableTypes
step.title: Demonstrate input variables of various types
step.description:
In this step, you enter a variety of variables.
This step demonstrates the various features of variables, including:
Booleans
Strings
Integers
Decimals
Times
Dates
The sample workflow in workflow_sample_wizards.xml demonstrates how variables can be used to substitute values into instructions and templates.

step.name: validationTypes
step.title: Demonstrate the pre-defined string types
step.description: Experiment by entering values for each of the validation types.
step.instructions:
This step demonstrates how a validationType attribute is used for a variable validation.
Four categories are used in this step:
Allowable characters
Data set related
Identity related
Network

step.name: varToSubOnly
step.title: Demostrate variable substitution only
step.description: In this step, the variable place-holder will be substituted with the variable value even though no variable reference is provided. The variable substitution will work properly, the only difference is that user will not be able to view or edit the variable in the step wizard.
step.instructions: In this example step, the simple string variable place holder will be substituted by its real time value: ${instance-String2}.

template.inlineTemplate: # 'echo' command to display string variable value echo Place holder is substituted with ${instance-String2}.

step.name: npis
step.title: Demonstrate the noPromptIfSet attribute
step.description: Notice how a variable widget is displayed, based on whether it already has a value. If you assigned the variable a value in the first step (or if you had previously assigned it a value while performing this step), the variable is displayed in a read-only widget. You can override the value by clicking on the information icon.
step.instructions:
This step shows how a variable is displayed, based on whether it already has a value. If you assigned it a value in the first step (or if you had previously assigned it a value while performing this step), the variable is displayed in a read-only widget. You can override the value by clicking on the information icon.
The sample workflow in workflow_sample_wizards.xml shows how variables can be used to substitute values into instructions and templates.
